business_title: Director of Communication, Center for Health Equity
business_title_phonetic: Director of Communication, Center for Health Equity
job_description: The newly created Center for Health Equity will align efforts in advancing health equity across the City and ensure that we deploy resources to reduce health and mental hygiene disparities across all neighborhoods in NYC.   The Center will work in collaboration with community-based partners, building on work the District Public Health Offices and others have pursued over the years.   The Center will focus on these key areas:  leveraging community assets to better integrate primary care and public health to serve the health needs of communities; building inter-agency collaboration to implement multi-sectorial approach to addressing the root causes of health disparities; and increasing organizational capacity that strengthens the agencyâ€™s lens of addressing health equity.   DUTIES WILL INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:   Our office is seeking a Director of Communication for Center for Health Equity (CHE) The Center is engage in a number of projects and requires a candidate with proficient analytic and communication skills.   This will involve having a thorough understanding that can impact systems and the environment as well as the ability to communicate effectively to a wide variety of audiences.   The successful candidate must be able to interact and work with all programs within the center, agency staff and community partners to ensure the goals and outcomes are met.   Oversees all communications activities for the Center, and works with Agency's Office of External Affairs to mutually determine priorities.   Acts as liaison between CHE and Agency's Media and Marketing.   --Communications and Intergovernmental offices, Acts as communications advisor to CHE management on issues such as: social media, publications, literature, special events and other communication venues.   -- Work closely with the Agency's Communications Office to ensure that CHE priorities are consistent with the Agency's.   -- Propose communications strategies to educate and raise awareness about DOHMH/CHE projects.   -- Provide leadership and guidance on message and materials development and, dissemination, and partners with the Agency's Office of External Affairs on strategy, development and production.   -- Propose a range of communication tools, materials and products including newsletters, e-newsletters, list-serves, social media sites (Tumblr), blogs, press releases, fact sheets, brochures, etc.
minimum_qual_requirements: 1. A Baccalaureate degree from an accredited college with 24 credits in English, journalism or public relations, plus five (5) years of full-time paid experience in public relations, journalism or advertising, including two (2) years in an administrative, supervisory or consultative capacity; or  2. A combination of education and/or experience which is equivalent to ''1'' above. Graduate study in English, journalism, or public relations may be substituted for up to one year of required experience. However, all candidates must have at least two (2) years of administrative, supervisory, or consultative experience in public relations, journalism or advertising.
preferred_skills: A working knowledge of government and community process and structures; experience working with media that targets varying racial and ethnic communities; experience in developing, writing, and editing a wide range of materials is important and ability to interpret, synthesize, and communicate technical information to non-technical audiences; considerable knowledge of social marketing and strategic communication strategies, working; experience in working on campaigns and/or community out.

job_description: **AMENDED in Hours and Salary Differential:  Proposed Salary Range:     $66.45 - $     71.18 (Hourly)  (37.5 hours/Week)  CMS II â€“ Hourly paid employees for the performance of supervisory duties = $ 5.82 (per hour)   The mission of the Bureau of Immunization (BOI) is to prevent the occurrence and transmission of diseases through immunization.  BOI promotes the immunization of children and adults against numerous vaccine preventable diseases (VPDs).  The unit is responsible for assuring the institution of control measures and outbreak response.   DUTIES WILL INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:   --Guide the analysis of surveillance data and communicate the status of the epidemiology of VPDs to the Assistant Commissioner.  -- Oversee maintenance of surveillance database and guide enhancements.  -- Oversee vaccine adverse event reporting.  -- Oversee reporting of VPD surveillance data to state and national authorities.  -- Explore research opportunities in existing data, pursue new research opportunities and expand VPD surveillance.  -- Identify and participate in special projects; past examples include implementing varicella surveillance in schools, assessing pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV13) effectiveness, and enhanced measles surveillance activities.  -- Responsible for identifying goals, meeting objectives and completing surveillance portions of the CDC grant.  -- Oversee Unit of 9 staff; define tasks and standards, conducting and/or overseeing annual performance evaluations of 5 staff, and pursuing disciplinary action when required.  -- Supervise staff who are at DOHMH for training purposes, maybe Council for State and Territorial Epidemiologists (CSTE) fellows, medical students or residents doing rotations or CDC trainees (such as Public Health Associate Program (PHAP)fellows).  -- Participate in emergency preparedness related Immunization issues.
minimum_qual_requirements: Possession of a valid license to practice medicine in the State of New York; and either:  a) Valid Board Certification issued by the appropriate American Specialty Board in any specialty area required by the agency; or  b) Current approved application on file for admission to the certifying examination given by the appropriate American Specialty Board in any specialty area required by the agency.  To be assigned to Assignment Level II, individuals must have, in addition to meeting the minimum qualification requirements for Assignment Level I described above, one year of satisfactory experience practicing in the specialty area.  To be assigned to Assignment Level III, individuals must possess:  a) A valid license to practice medicine in the State of New York; and  b) A Master's degree in Public Health, or equivalent Master's degree, including or supplemented by graduate credits in epidemiology and biostatistics. Completion of Epidemic Intelligence Service program of the Center for Disease Control and Prevention may be used to substitute for this Master's degree; and  c) At least two years of satisfactory experience after receipt of the Master's degree, or equivalent, in the practice of epidemiology. Specialty Board Certification or eligibility may be substituted for one year of this experience.  To be assigned to Assignment Level IV, individuals must possess:  a) A valid license to practice medicine in the State of New York; and  b) Completion of an approved residency program in an accredited hospital, including three years of experience, in either internal medicine, or family practice, or pediatrics, or another related specialty area required by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene; and  c) Valid board certification or board eligibility issued by the appropriate American Subspecialty Board in Infectious Disease, Pulmonary Medicine, or a related subspecialty; and  d) Completion of an approved fellowship program in an accredited hospital, including two years of experience, in either infectious diseases, or pulmonary medicine, or another related subspecialty required by the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.
preferred_skills: --A minimum of 2 years of experience in surveillance, data analysis, and epidemiological methods;  -- Experience leading outbreak investigations;  -- supervisory experience with demonstrated management skills;  -- demonstrated ability to communicate findings and results in written presentation;   --knowledge of vaccine-preventable diseases Foundation in SAS, SQL, SPSS, MS Access and other statistical analysis and database software;  --excellent interpersonal, communication and presentation skills.

job_description: **OPEN TO PERMANENT ASSOCIATE STAFF ANALYSTS ONLY. YOU MUST CLEARLY STATE YOUR CIVIL SERVICE STATUS ON YOUR RESUME OR COVER LETTER. ALL OTHER CANDIDATES WILL NOT BE CONSIDERED.    The Division of Disease Control at the New York City (NYC) Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH) is responsible for the identification, surveillance, treatment, control and prevention of infectious diseases in NYC. The Division includes several large programs: Bureau of Communicable Disease, Bureau of HIV/AIDS Prevention and Control, Bureau of Immunization, Bureau of Sexually Transmitted Diseases Prevention and Control, Bureau of Tuberculosis and the Public Health Laboratory.     The Division of Disease Control is seeking a highly motivated individual to work in the Public Health Laboratory.    Responsibilities will include, but not limited to:     â€¢	Manage procurement and financing of equipment and supplies (e.g., reagents) necessary for functioning of â€œrapid responseâ€ teams and other laboratory functions.    â€¢	Supervise directly a number of supervisory/professional personnel responsible for the day-to-day operations of the Public Health Laboratory.    â€¢	Coordinate with hospitals and clinical laboratories to assess inventory of equipment and supplies to handle processing of Ebola and related infectious specimens.     â€¢	Review contract proposals, purchase requests, and performance reports to ensure compliance with the agency's requirements, and federal/state/city guidelines.    â€¢	Track and analyze spending by disease and forecast budget needs, as well as review budgetary proposals and financial reports.    â€¢	Manage inventory of equipment and supplies necessary for processing of Ebola and other infectious specimens.    â€¢	Make recommendations to higher management concerning the awarding of contracts, finance, and the provision of additional funding or defunding of contracted programs.     â€¢	Coordinate laboratory support to rapid response teams (e.g., transfer of specimens).    â€¢	Participate in emergency preparedness and response activities at Public Health Laboratory site.

job_description: DEP is the largest combined municipal water and wastewater utility in the country, with nearly 6,000 employees. We deliver 1.1 billion gallons of high quality drinking water per day to 8.3 million New York City residents and more than 1 million people in Upstate New York, and we collect and treat an average of 1.3 billion gallons of wastewater per day. DEPâ€™s annual operating budget is $3.7 billion and our workforce is spread out over NYC and also upstate NY where we support our watershed and security operations.     The Office of Organizational Development is charged with leading, planning, designing and successfully implementing workforce and organizational strategies to achieve DEPâ€™s vision and mission and an organizational culture aligned with our core values.     Under varying levels of managerial direction, with varying degrees of latitude for independent initiative, judgment and decision, performs difficult and responsible professional work and models our values in support of the Office of Organizational Development. Reporting directly to the Director of Employee Engagement & Performance Management, the Engagement and Communications Project Specialist will be responsible for implementing engagement projects; developing internal communications to motivate, engage, and educate the Agencyâ€™s workforce;  provide strategic and tactical deployment support of all engagement initiatives; assist in developing, leading, and reporting on organizational surveys, focus groups and related activities; identify, design, develop, write, edit and manage a wide range of internal communications materials including newsletters/articles, presentations, online copy, brochures, scripts, videos and memos; create media and/or edit communications materials to insure alignment and continuity with DEP goals and strategies; collaborate with organizational leaders and bureaus to engage employees who work in geographically dispersed locations and in a wide range of employee functions/populations; use digital and other technology media and resources to engage employees and achieve outcomes; assist with writing of memos, designing presentations and content specific to events (i.e., town halls, webcasts); participate in networking meetings or other functional/internal client programs, as required.

The Bureau of School Health (BSH) provides direct school health services to over 1.3 million general education children in public and non-public schools in New York City. Its mission is to promote the total health of school children in this city. They advocate for the health and well-being of the children and adolescents of New York City. BSH has been the provider of public health services in the schools for 100 years.     DUTIES WILL INCLUDE BUT NOT BE LIMITED TO:     The Public Health Nurse III will serve as a resource to the Regional school staff, parents and community agencies.    -- Oversee and monitor the implementation of program policies and special projects within an assigned area.    -- Supervise and evaluate nursing and paraprofessional staff through field visits.    -- Supervise Office of School Health staff within an assigned area.    --Provide assignments and schedules for nursing and paraprofessional staff.    -- Utilize Automated Student Health Record (ASHR) to generate reports.    -- Conduct in-service trainings and plan staff development activities.    -- Participate in recruitment and orientation of new staff and will be responsible for maintaining inventory of medical supplies and equipment within a designed area.    -- Serve on emergency teams which are on call for all future bioterrorism attacks within the City of New York as well as all emergencies as directed by the Commissioner of the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.

business_title: Correctional Counselor, Bureau of Correctional Health Services
business_title_phonetic: Correctional Counselor, Bureau of Correctional Health Services
work_location: Hazen St-West Facil, E. Elm, N
job_description: The Division of Prevention & Primary Care (PPC) was created to promote the availability of quality health care services in NYC through various programs.  This is being accomplished by creating mechanisms and tools to promote access to quality health care for the uninsured, underinsured, and for inmates housed in New York City correctional system; oversight and evaluation of health insurance programs and health services to ensure high quality and maximum access for targeted populations, including those with special needs; promoting a general awareness and understanding of available health services; and providing leadership to health care and human services community in planning and developing programs that support the mission of the Division.          The Bureau of Transitional Health Care Coordination (THCC) is responsible for overseeing health education programs and coordinating community collaborations to facilitate linkages to health care for those leaving City jails with chronic health conditions such as hypertension, diabetes, and asthma as well as STDs and HIV/AIDS. The services of THCC are integrated with other programs in the Bureau of Correctional Health Services (CHS) and the Bureau of Primary Care Access & Planning (PCAP).  It also has partnerships with other DOHMH programs, the District Public Health Offices, other City agencies and community-based providers throughout the City. In addition, THCC works closely with the jail based health providers to facilitate continuity of care from intake jails to community health care for those in City jails including those with chronic/communicable health conditions including HIV/AIDS returning to the communities of greatest health disparities who face multiple social service issues, who are unemployed or under-employed.     SPECIFIC DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES    -- Meet with and interview clients (SUD, HIV and other patients in need of preventive and primary care) and conduct a needs assessment.    -- Conduct treatment readiness/ health education/counseling sessions.    --Determine eligibility for community-based resources based on presenting health and social assessment (housing, treatment, care and services).    -- Identify appropriate community-based service providers based on client's needs and obtain needed consents.    -- Make appointments and/or provide referral information for community-based providers.    -- Serve as a liaison between clients and community based service providers.    -- Maintain client records and update as needed.    -- Prepare pre-release documentation for clients with a projected release date.    -- Maintain documentation of services provided and referrals made.    -- Ensure that all data is properly updated and entered in systems.    -- Provide community program staff with client-level information in order to verify linkage to care.    -- Provide brief counselling interventions for substance use disorders.
minimum_qual_requirements: Qualification Requirements  1. A four year high school diploma or its educational equivalent and four years of satisfactory full-time experience providing direct counseling, guidance, crisis-intervention or information and referral services, for inmates of a correctional facility, substance abusers, or a similar client population; or     2. Education and experience equivalent to ''1'' above.  Thirty (30) semester credits from an accredited college will be considered equivalent to one year of the required experience.  However, all candidates must have a four year high school diploma or its educational equivalent and at least one year of experience as described in ''1'' above.

business_title: Surveillance Analyst, Bureau of Environmental Disease and Injury Prevention
business_title_phonetic: Surveillance Analyst, Bureau of Environmental Disease and Injury Prevention
job_description: **OPEN TO PERMANENT PUBLIC HEALTH EPIDEMIOLOGISTS.  YOU MUST CLEARLY STATE YOUR CIVIL SERVICE STATUS ON YOUR RESUME OR COVER LETTER.  ALL OTHER CANDIDATES WILL NOT BE CONSIDERED.    The Bureau of Environmental Disease and Injury Prevention's (EDIP) mission is to prevent environmental disease and injury in homes, communities and the workplace, and to protect health by promoting healthy environments and health equity. EDIP conducts research and surveillance and develops policies and programs to prevent illnesses, injuries and death. EDIP has 3 Programs - Healthy Homes, Environmental Health Assessment and Communications, and Injury and Violence Prevention and 3 support Offices - Research and Surveillance, Policy and Programming, and Emergency Planning and Operations. This active surveillance position is located within the Healthy Homes Program under the supervision of the Deputy Director of the Hosuing Interventions and Special Projects unit. job_description: The New York City Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) protects public health and the environment by supplying clean drinking water, collecting and treating wastewater, and reducing air, noise, and hazardous materials pollution. DEP is the largest combined municipal water and wastewater utility in the country, with nearly 6,000 employees. We deliver 1.1 billion gallons of high quality drinking water per day to 8.3 million New York City residents and more than 1 million people in Upstate New York, and we collect and treat an average of 1.3 billion gallons of wastewater per day. job_description: DoITT provides for the sustained, efficient and effective delivery of IT services, infrastructure and telecommunications to enhance service delivery to New York City's residents, businesses, employees and visitors. As the City's technology leader, DoITT is responsible for maintaining the foundational IT infrastructure and systems that touch every aspect of City life from public safety to human services, from education to economic development crossing the full spectrum of governmental operations.    The successful candidate will serve as the Risk & Issue Manager reporting to the Emergency Communications Transformation Program (ECTP), the single point of contact responsible for managing Risks and Issues (R&Is) across ECTP's Program Management Office.  Responsibilities will include: Managing both technical and non-technical R&Is identified by all ECTP Project Managers, Engineers, Analysts and Testers, as well as by ECTP PMO partner agencies (e.g., DDC, DoITT, FDNY, and NYPD); leading the entire R&I management effort, which includes evaluating, documenting, and implementing all processes and procedures that support risk/issue identification, mitigation/resolution planning, status monitoring, and escalations to the ECTP Risk Management Team; facilitating communications across the ECTP PMO throughout execution of the R&I management process; managing program-level risks and issues, supporting owners on identification, mitigation/resolution planning, and ensuring status is current and plans remain viable; overseeing maintenance of ECTP Risk Register and Issue Log, producing weekly status from the program tool set; developing, implementing and monitoring adherence to criteria for consistent ranking of risk and issue impacts across the program; providing support for project-level risk identification, mitigation planning, status monitoring and escalation, as required; weekly tracking of program- and project-level issues and the progress of associated resolution plans throughout the delivery lifecycle, ensuring appropriate owners are assigned and engaged in maintaining effective resolution plans; developing metrics and reports on analysis related to root causes, issue trends, plan progress, closures, and escalations; providing feedback on repetitive issues to appropriate audiences for future prevention, engaging PMO, stakeholder agencies, and vendors owning those issues, and using experience and organizational savvy to bring together diverse teams to complete planned resolution activities timely; staff to the ECTP Risk Management Team, supporting their review of program R&Is; preparing meeting materials for distribution in advance, presenting R&Is, and making recommendations on the appropriateness of assigned owners, effectiveness of mitigation actions/response plans, options for best course of action, closure or escalation of high severity R&Is; preparing presentations or other materials to summarize R&I status and analysis, document decisions and necessary follow up actions; and any other ad-hoc ECTP projects or initiatives, as assigned.
minimum_qual_requirements: (1) A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college, including or supplemented by twenty-four (24) semester credits in computer science or a related computer field and two (2) years of satisfactory full-time software experience in designing, programming, debugging, maintaining, implementing, and enhancing computer software applications, systems programming, systems analysis and design, data communication software, or database design and programming, including one year in a project leader capacity or as a major contributor on a complex project; or  (2) A four-year high school diploma or its educational equivalent and six (6) years of full-time satisfactory software experience as described in â€œ1'' above, including one year in a project leader capacity or as a major contributor on a complex project; or  (3) A satisfactory combination of education and experience that is equivalent to (1) or (2) above. College education may be substituted for up to two years of the required experience in (2) above on the basis that sixty (60) semester credits from an accredited college is equated to one year of experience. A masters degree in computer science or a related computer field may be substituted for one year of the required experience in (1) or (2) above. However, all candidates must have a four year high school diploma or its educational equivalent, plus at least one (1) year of satisfactory full-time software experience in a project leader capacity or as a major contributor on a complex project.  NOTE: In order to have your experience accepted as Project Leader or Major Contributor experience, you must explain in detail how your experience qualifies you as a project leader or as a major contributor. Experience in computer operations, technical support, quality assurance (QA), hardware installation, help desk, or as an end user will not be accepted for meeting the minimum qualification  requirements.  Special Note  To be eligible for placement in Assignment Level IV, in addition to the Qualification Requirements stated above, individuals must have one year of satisfactory experience in a project leader capacity or as a major contributor on a complex project in data administration, database management systems, operating systems, data communications systems, capacity planning, and/or on-line applications programming.
preferred_skills: The successful candidate should possess the following:5+ years risk/issue management experience; experience performing risk and issue management-related tasks on large systems integration projects for mission critical processes; proven experience in managing issues/risks for solutions in multiple-entity environments (multiple agencies, business partners, etc.); proven experience creating and managing logs, registers and tracking tools, experience with Clarity tool preferred; understanding of formal SDLC methodologies, including iterative and incremental development as well as agile development methods preferred; ability to see tasks through to completion without significant guidance and exhibit meticulous attention to detail; high level of effective decision-making and negotiating skills; ability to effectively interface/communicate with all levels of internal and external personnel, technical and non-technical resources; ability to read, analyze, interpret, and take actions/base decisions from/on complex documents; ability to manage multiple priorities simultaneously; strong verbal and written communication ability and time management skills; critical thinker with ability to provide insight and thought leadership in support of risk mitigation and issue resolution planning; public safety and/or NYC government experience a plus.

job_description: Under the direction of the Director of Bronx Planning, the Planner undertakes Borough Planning activities related to the development of affordable housing in the Bronx.  The Planner is responsible for managing, tracking, reporting, and ensuring that entitlement and development approval activities are undertaken in a timely, efficient, and effective manner.    The goal of the Planning Division is to ensure that HPD investments are leveraging and incentivizing other public and private investments to achieve broader community objectives that strengthen the social, economic, and physical health of neighborhoods.  Borough Planning consists of a team of planners responsible for managing the entitlement and development approval process for the development of city-owned parcels and/or projects financed or sponsored by HPD for the development of affordable housing.    All planners in the Planning Division are expected to perform similar duties and responsibilities to ensure a flexible and multi-disciplined team.  Selected duties for the Borough Planning team include analyzing development trends, and neighborhood and market dynamics; land use and zoning analysis; coordinating with Predevelopment Planners in the requests for proposals review and selection process; and, managing the critical path toward project entitlement and development financial closing.  The Borough Planning team works collaboratively with Predevelopment Planning team, and participates in Neighborhood Planning efforts.  The Borough Planning team works with other NYC agencies, such as the Economic Development Corporation, Department of City Planning, for- and non- profit housing and community developers, Community Boards and local organizations, public officials, and neighborhood residents through the predevelopment process.  All Planners within the Planning Division are expected to participate and assist in neighborhood workshops, as necessary.
minimum_qual_requirements: 1. A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college and two years of experience in community work or community centered activities in an area related to the duties described above; or  2. High school graduation or equivalent and six years of experience in community work or community centered activities in an area related to the duties as described above; or  3. Education and/or experience which is equivalent to ''1'' or ''2'' above. However, all candidates must have at least one year of experience as described in ''1'' above.
preferred_skills: 1. Thorough knowledge of New York City government and housing issues.      2. Knowledge of zoning, land use planning, and urban renewal requirements.      3. Successful experience working with community boards, civic associations, and neighborhood groups.      4. Experience with community-based planning and neighborhood development issues.      5. Experience conducting studies, writing reports, and conducting meetings with community and interagency partners.      6. Ability to work independently, take initiative, and work effectively with others.      7. Excellent research, analytical, writing, and public speaking skills.      8. Demonstrated ability to meet deadlines and manage multiple projects in a timely manner.    9. Knowledge of database and presentation applications (including Excel, Access and PowerPoint) and GIS mapping applications.    10. Candidates with masters degrees in urban planning and at least two years of experience in urban planning and, preferably, practical application of real estate principles in finance and/or development are strongly preferred.

job_description: The New York City Department of Youth and Community Development (DYCD) funds and supports youth and community services through contracts with a broad network of community-based organizations (CBO) throughout New York City.  Our central task is administering available city, state, and federal funds to a wide range of innovative, high quality programs that positively impact youth and communities.      The evaluation unit works with all DYCD programmatic units, including the Planning, Research and Program Development and the Capacity Building units; external evaluation firms; representatives of the CBO community and other City agencies and units; as well as other stakeholders.  A dramatic expansion of COMPASS (the Comprehensive After School System of NYC) now underway requires system-wide evaluation, which is being conducted by an external evaluation firm.  Evaluations of other DYCD initiatives are planned or are underway, some of which will be contracted out and others will be carried out internally.      Reporting to the Senior Director of Evaluation, the Deputy Director will be a ''thought partner'' with other units to help develop and set goals and outcomes for initiatives and internal trainings, as well as help turn evaluation findings into recommendations for changing the practice of DYCD and its CBOs.  Ideally, the Deputy Director will have experience with youth development and community development programs as well with as evaluation and data analysis.      The Deputy Director will be responsible for:     â€¢	Designing, executing and interpreting results of studies that evaluate various DYCD initiatives, including: drafting evaluation procedures and data collection tools; conducting and supervising data collection and analysis; and preparing reports and briefs for varied stakeholders (data collection activities would include site visits, observing program operations, interviewing program staff, reviewing written and administrative data and records, and other related activities);  â€¢	Assisting the Senior Director of Evaluation in monitoring evaluation studies performed by external evaluators;  â€¢	Critiquing draft evaluation reports and analyses by external evaluation firms and recommending areas for further inquiry and analysis;   â€¢	Supporting the Director of Evaluation by preparing summaries and reports of evaluation studies, testimony, memoranda, correspondence and other written material for hearings, oversight entities and the public;  â€¢	Presenting results of evaluation and research studies in writing and orally to multiple stakeholders;  â€¢	Participating in and conducting meetings with multiple stakeholders, including all DYCD units, external evaluation firms, representatives of the CBO community and other City agencies and units;  â€¢	Conducting trainings on program evaluation methods and techniques for DYCD staff and representatives of the CBO community;  â€¢	Serving on an IRB committee.

job_description: This position will report to the Director of the HIV Prevention in the Bureau of HIV/AIDS Prevention and Control (BHIV). Under this leadership, the Director of Program Planning is expected to research, develop, and plan implementation of evidence-based policy and planning recommendations concerning best practices for HIV prevention programmatic implementation in New York City (NYC).     The Director will research both national and international models. She/he will assess applicability of innovative HIV prevention activities for the NYC setting and create a program plan to operationalize these activities in the context of long-term HIV prevention planning.    Specifically, tasks will include:     -- In coordination with other directors in the Prevention Program, develop new requests for proposals (RFPs) to competitively award Health Department funding to community and clinical partners citywide.  These RFPs should be completely evidence-based and developed in collaboration with senior members of the HIV Prevention team and with the Director of Business Systems.      -- Conduct comprehensive clinical and public health research of secondary sources (e.g., published and gray literature review) to identify possible new interventions for HIV prevention with applicability to the NYC environment.  Educate HIV prevention team about the findings.     -- Work across the Bureau and with the various community planning groups to create a long term, comprehensive strategic plan that will serve to maximize achievement of HIV Prevention and Care/Treatment Program goals and objectives and service delivery, using above research findings and a service gap analysis. Included in this comprehensive strategic plan will be prioritized recommendations for implementation of new HIV prevention interventions.     -- Work closely with the Care and Treatment Director of Research and Evaluation, the Deputy Director of HIV Prevention, the Director of the Epidemiology and Field Services Program and other units/programs within the Bureau of HIV/AIDS Prevention and Control to obtain needed data for the planning process.    -- Assess and make recommendations concerning partnerships with community-based institutions/organizations as well as academic and other institutions for HIV prevention activities.    -- Develop and operationalize HIV prevention pilot projects.    --Based on priorities set by the Bureau and the Director of HIV Prevention, identify new grant funding, write grants, and coordinate grant submission process to increase funding for HIV Prevention program activities in NYC.     -- Lead planning of implementation of new programs in coordination with leadership from the Programs Unit, including identification of needed materials, curricula and trainings; interaction with staff/contractors involved in development of materials, curricula and trainings; and coordination with staff across the BHIV to ensure that such materials, curricula and trainings are developed in a timely and appropriate manner.       -- Work closely with the community HIV Planning Group (HPG) and other HIV-related planning groups, as needed, to collaborate on strategic plan/programming development, and to communicate planning goals, objectives and model outputs.     -- Collaborate with other DOHMH Bureaus and departments within BHIV to find synergies for HIV prevention programs.     -- Represent the DOHMH at meetings as required.    -- Supervise the Director of Risk Reduction in Vulnerable Populations.

Experience in computer operations, technical support, quality assurance (QA), hardware installation, help desk, or as an end user will not be accepted for meeting the minimum qualification  requirements.  Special Note  To be eligible for placement in Assignment Level IV, in addition to the Qualification Requirements stated above, individuals must have one year of satisfactory experience in a project leader capacity or as a major contributor on a complex project in data administration, database management systems, operating systems, data communications systems, capacity planning, and/or on-line applications programming.
preferred_skills: The successful candidate should possess the following: 5+ years of experience project managing IT infrastructure and applications projects (end-to-end); 3+ years of experience in Vendor management; WBS creation; project and resource planning; proficiency in Microsoft Project, and other project management software; Proficiency in PowerPoint; Strong demonstration of negotiation and conflict management skills; Strong visual presentation skills; strong public speaking skills; excellent leadership and organization skills in an aggressive timeframe; ability to be a systems thinker, attention to quality, and relationship and team building; ability to interact effectively with staff, project managers, and functional managers; strong and articulate verbal and written communication skills; ability to interface with executive level management and give senior level presentations; PMP certification and experience working with City of New York agencies.

job_description: The New York City Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) protects public health and the environment by supplying clean drinking water, collecting and treating wastewater, and reducing air, noise and hazardous materials pollution.  DEP is the largest combined municipal water and wastewater utility in the country, with nearly 6,000 employees.  We deliver 1.1 billion gallons of high quality drinking water per day to 8.3 million New York City residents and more than 1 million people in Upstate New York, and we collect and treat an average of 1.3 billion gallons of wastewater per day.  â€œThe Bureau of Customer Services (BCS) oversees the production and collection of water and sewer bills along with all the work required to maintain our citywide network of meters and meter reading devices.  BCS serves approximately 836,000 customers and generates $3.6 billion of revenue annually.  BCS is seeking an experienced Customer Service supervisor to serve in the capacity of Chief Clerk in one of borough offices.  The borough office is a walk-in facility responsible for assisting customer inquiries relating to water and waste water charges.  The selected candidate, under the general supervision of Borough Manager, with latitude for independent initiative and judgment, will perform professional administrative work related to the daily operations of the Borough office.  He/She will supervise clerical and administrative employees engaged in the billing of water and wastewater charges; prepare quarterly and annual performance evaluations for staff; coach and mentor staff; monitor time and leave; enforce Agency policy and initiate disciplinary action as needed.  The candidate will review, analyze, and resolve complex account complaints referred by the Borough Manager, department supervisors, and outside agencies.  Additional responsibilities include: responding to internal/external customers inquiries, explaining complex account transaction histories; training staff in the use of the Bureauâ€™s Customer Information System (CIS) and other systems; coordinating special projects and implementing quality controls to ensure the satisfactory completion of the officeâ€™s workload and developing action plans to performance issues. The selected candidate may be required to work overtime, participate in community â€œoutreachâ€ events, attend meetings and serve as a liaison with other City agencies on billing and customer service issues.    Only candidates with expertise in BCS policies, procedures, processes and systems will be considered.  Requires the use of automated offices systems (e.g., Microsoft Word, Excel, BAPPS, CIS).  Strong analytical and written skills.  Demonstrates professional customer service skills.    NOTE: Must be permenant civil service title of Principal Administrative Associate.
minimum_qual_requirements: 1. A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college and three years of satisfactory full-time progressively responsible  clerical/administrative  experience, one year of which must have been in an administrative capacity or supervising staff performing  clerical/administrative  work of more than moderate difficulty;  or  2. An associate degree or 60 semester credits from an accredited college and four years of satisfactory full-time progressively responsible  clerical/administrative  experience including one year of the administrative supervisory experience described in  ''1''  above;  or  3. A four-year high school diploma or its educational equivalent approved by a State's department of education or a recognized accrediting organization and five years of satisfactory full-time progressively responsible  clerical/administrative  experience including one year of the administrative supervisory experience as described in  ''1''  above;  4. Education and/or experience equivalent to  ''1'',  ''2'',  or  ''3''  above.  However, all candidates must possess the one year of administrative or supervisory experience as described in  ''1''  above.  Education above the high school level may be substituted for the general clerical/administrative experience (but not for the one year of administrative or supervisory experience described in  ''1''  above) at a rate of 30 semester credits from an accredited college for 6 months of experience up to a maximum of 3Â½ years.

job_description: The New York City Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) protects public health and the environment by supplying clean drinking water, collecting and treating wastewater, and reducing air, noise, and hazardous materials pollution. DEP is the largest combined municipal water and wastewater utility in the country with nearly 6,000 employees. We deliver 1.1 billion gallons of high quality drinking water per day to 8.3 million New York City residents and more than 1 million people in Upstate New York and we collect and treat an average of 1.3 billion gallons of wastewater per day.    The Bureau of Water Supply seeks to hire an Instrumentation Specialist (IS) II to work within the Watershed Water Quality Operations Kingston Laboratory, in upstate Kingston, NY. Under direction with some latitude for independent judgment and decision making, the IS will install, inspect, and test complex water quality instruments, controls and telemetry equipment at various field locations. They will make periodic inspections of instrumentation, report unusual malfunctions, and perform routine preventive maintenance. The IS will dismantle and reassemble equipment for corrective maintenance or for replacement in whole or part. They will operate, test, and calibrate pH, temperature and turbidity, and other instrumentation. The IS may install small piping and tubing where necessary. They will keep records and maintain logs of work performed and make recommendations regarding improvement of materials and equipment at various locations. The IS will perform routine laboratory quality control procedures according to ELAP (Environmental Laboratory Approval Program) protocols and maintain accurate records. The IS must comply with applicable environmental, health & safety regulations and DEPâ€™s policies and procedures.
minimum_qual_requirements: (1) An associate degree in electrical construction and instrumentation, electrical engineering technology, mechanical engineering technology, electromechanical engineering technology, or electronic engineering technology from a college or university, accredited by regional, national, professional or specialized agencies recognized as accrediting bodies by the U.S. Secretary of Education and by the Council for Higher Education Accreditation (CHEA), AND one year of full-time satisfactory experience within the last ten years in the installation, maintenance and repair of electronic instrumentation and control systems, including microprocessors, and electrical and pneumatic instrumentation and control systems; or    (2) Graduation from a trade, technical or vocational school approved by a Stateâ€™s Department of Education or a recognized accrediting organization with a major course of study in electrical, electronic, electromechanical or mechanical technology AND three years of full-time satisfactory experience as described in ''1'' above; or    (3) A four-year high school diploma or its educational equivalent approved by a Stateâ€™s Department of Education or a recognized accrediting organization AND four years of full-time satisfactory experience as described in ''1'' above.    College education leading to a degree in one of the areas of study described in ''1'' above may be substituted only in ''2'' or ''3'' above for a maximum of three years of experience at the rate of 30 semester credits for one year of full-time satisfactory experience. If you have moving violations, license suspension(s) or an accident record, you may be disqualified. This license must be maintained for the duration of your employment.    1. job_description: The New York City Commission on Human Rights (The Commission) is the agency charged with enforcing the New York City Human Rights Law (NYCHRL) â€“ one of the most expansive civil rights laws in the nation â€“ which prohibits discrimination in employment, public accommodations, and housing for a variety of protected groups, and prohibits bias-related harassment and bias-based profiling.  Through its Law Enforcement Bureau (LEB), the Commission accepts claims filed by the public, and has the power to initiate its own investigations to affirmatively root out discrimination, harassment, and retaliation and other violations of the NYCHRL. Agency Attorneys work within the Law Enforcement Bureau. The Commissionâ€™s Community Relations Bureau â€œCRBâ€-is empowered to take action against prejudice, intolerance, bigotry, discrimination and bias-related violence or harassment through education, trainings, outreach efforts, and other mechanisms aimed at creating partnerships and relationships with stakeholders in the community.  Both bureaus collaborate closely to work towards the shared goal of fostering mutual understanding and respect among all New Yorkers and encouraging equality of treatment throughout New York City. job_description: The Department of Design and Construction, Division of Public Buildings seeks Project Managers to work for the Division of Public Buildings within various units. In this capacity, the candidates will be responsible for technical work, preparing construction documents, administering field activities; and reviewing proposals, including technical data. In addition, the candidates will serve as a liaison for DDC, contractors, and client agencies.  Selected candidates will also prepare scopes for purchasing of required equipment and materials; and supervise and generate reports on project schedules and construction staff.
minimum_qual_requirements: Qualification Requirements    1.
